Speaker: NA
Text: The bill as returned to us by the Senate is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite unacceptable to the government. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: that was passed through this parliament last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, and again a few weeks ago, was a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: and balanced piece of legislation. It already

Speaker: NA
Text: represented a major compromise. It represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed a fair balancing of the interests of all

Speaker: NA
Text: sections of the Australian community. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: fair as between Aborigines and farmers; it

Speaker: NA
Text: was fair as between city and country; it was

Speaker: NA
Text: fair as between Australian and Australian.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bill as amended by the Senate will not

Speaker: NA
Text: treat farmers and Aborigines equally. The bill

Speaker: NA
Text: as amended by the Senate gives special

Speaker: NA
Text: privileges to one group of Australians denied

Speaker: NA
Text: to others. It contains provisions which are not

Speaker: NA
Text: available to other sections of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: community and are specifically available to

Speaker: NA
Text: one group of Australians, and that group of

Speaker: NA
Text: (137); Australians alone. It is a fundamental of our

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of society, and it is certainly a funda-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental of the approach of my government,

Speaker: NA
Text: that all Australians should be treated equally

Speaker: NA
Text: before the law. All Australians should be

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to an equal dispensation of justice,

Speaker: NA
Text: and all Australians should have equal respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities before the law.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are four major objections which the

Speaker: NA
Text: government has to the bill as amended by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate. They surround the areas that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been debated at length over the past weeks

Speaker: NA
Text: and the past months. They relate, firstly, to

Speaker: NA
Text: the right to negotiate, secondly, to the regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration test, thirdly, to the application

Speaker: NA
Text: Racial Discrimination Act to this piece of

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and, fourthly, to the so-called

Speaker: NA
Text: sunset clause.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have long argued that it is wrong in

Speaker: NA
Text: principle that there should be a right to

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiate over pastoralleaseholdings subject

Speaker: NA
Text: to mining applications in the hands of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: digenous claimants, yet that right is not

Speaker: NA
Text: available to farmers and pastoralists. We do

Speaker: NA
Text: not believe that that right should be available

Speaker: NA
Text: to one group and not available to others.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the fundamental reason why we

Speaker: NA
Text: have always said that a bill which contained

Speaker: NA
Text: the right to negotiate was always going to be

Speaker: NA
Text: unacceptable, not only to the rural community

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australia, not only to the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: industry of Australia, but indeed to the vast

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk of the Australian community, who

Speaker: NA
Text: believe in a very sacred principle, that is,

Speaker: NA
Text: equality of all Australians before the law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I would remind the parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: that when the original native title legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: was passed at the behest of the Keating

Speaker: NA
Text: government in 1993 it was never intended

Speaker: NA
Text: that the right to negotiate should apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: pastoral leaseholdings. Nothing which has

Speaker: NA
Text: happened in all the hours, all the weeks and

Speaker: NA
Text: all the months of the debate that has gone on

Speaker: NA
Text: since the High Court brought down its deci-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion in the Wik case in December 1996 has

Speaker: NA
Text: disturbed that unassailable historical fact

Speaker: NA
Text: the original legislation was predicated on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis that the grant of a pastoral leasehold

Speaker: NA
Text: extinguished native title.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was contained in a preamble to the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1993 act. It was asserted by Mr Keating, my

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessor as Prime Minister. That assur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance, that assumption, that statement, that

Speaker: NA
Text: declaration of belief was contained in corres-

Speaker: NA
Text: pondence which passed between the then

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and some premiers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian states. It was the belief and the

Speaker: NA
Text: assumption under which the former Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Premier of Queensland, Wayne Goss, operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ed. It was always believed, even by prominent

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the indigenous community, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the idea that native title should have survived

Speaker: NA
Text: the grant of a valid pastoral lease was com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely unacceptable. The whole basis of all

Speaker: NA
Text: of our understanding was that that was an

Speaker: NA
Text: of the unassailable fact.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then to our very great surprise the High

Speaker: NA
Text: Court of Australia decided in December 1996

Speaker: NA
Text: that that was not necessarily so. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: many people then with a great deal of justifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation, including many of the farmers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and all of the state premiers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia-and I say advisedly: all of the state

Speaker: NA
Text: premiers of Australia-including the Premier

Speaker: NA
Text: of New South Wales, Mr Bob Carr, who said

Speaker: NA
Text: that the proper response of the government in

Speaker: NA
Text: the wake of the High Court decision was in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact to pass a law that simply confirmed the

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the parliament and, the

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the Australian people in

Speaker: NA
Text: December of 1993 that the grant of a valid

Speaker: NA
Text: pastoral lease extinguished native title.

Speaker: NA
Text: That was the pressure under which my

Speaker: NA
Text: government was placed, and that was the

Speaker: NA
Text: the view of many of my colleagues who now sit

Speaker: NA
Text: behind me, not only in the National Party, but

Speaker: NA
Text: also in the Liberal Party, because they believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that is what the Australian people had been

Speaker: NA
Text: promised, guaranteed and led to believe by

Speaker: NA
Text: the former Labor Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: But, because of our respect for the decision

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by the High Court and because of our

Speaker: NA
Text: belief that we had to properly balance the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of farmers and Aborigines, we said,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'No, we will not embrace that course of

Speaker: NA
Text: action, but what we will seek to do is estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: that lish a legislative structure-which was ulti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately embodied in the lO-point plan and

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently in the Native Title Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill-that would enshrine the principles of

Speaker: NA
Text: equality of treatment, respect the principles of

Speaker: NA
Text: native title laid down in the Mabo case,

Speaker: NA
Text: confirm the interpretation of that in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to pastoral leaseholdings enunciated in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Wik decision, and present it to the people as

Speaker: NA
Text: a fair and decent compromise.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: of New South Wales, who argued very

Speaker: NA

Text: the Wik decision and therefore should have

Speaker: NA
Text: leaseholdings in the schedule to the Native

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: cism from those people-the government said

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the legislative framework that it had estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court decision that overturned that

Speaker: NA
Text: exception; a refusal by my government to

Speaker: NA
Text: simply embrace the extinguishment option in

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: ing many of my own party supporters and

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: tives of the rural community of Australia,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I say to the farmers of Australia: although
